    From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

    The Criterion logo

    The Criterion Collection is a video distribution company which specializes in licensing and selling "important classic and contemporary films" in "editions that offer the highest technical quality and award-winning, original supplements."[1][2] Janus Films and the Voyager Company established The Criterion Collection in 1984 as a privately held company concentrating exclusively upon the North American home video market. Aside from three early rare titles on VHS and Betamax cassette,[3][4] between 1984 and 1998 Criterion published home video releases exclusively on the LaserDisc format, pioneering now standard features such as letterboxing, audio commentary tracks, and other supplemental content. In 1998, Criterion shifted from LaserDiscs into the then fledgling DVD market, and has since issued over 1,000 DVD and Blu-ray releases. In 2021, 4K Ultra HD releases were announced to launch starting with Citizen Kane in November.[5] All of Criterion's LaserDisc releases have since gone out of print.[6]

    DVD, Blu-ray and 4K Ultra HD releases[edit]

    Legend
    — Film has not been released on that format or series.
    † A DVD or Blu-ray release currently out of print – all LaserDisc editions are out of print.
    ‡ A DVD, Blu-ray, or 4K Ultra HD release that has been announced but has not yet been released.
    § A 4K Ultra HD + Blu-ray combo disc version has been released.
    * Boxed set or compilation (see Boxed sets section for a full listing of the titles included).
    ± Announced on LaserDisc and was not released, but was released on DVD or Blu-ray.
    LaserDisc releases with two catalog numbers refer to releases in the CAV and CLV formats, respectively.
    The "Art House" column notes stand-alone releases of a film within the "Essential Art House" series.
    Some films are available through the "Essential Art House" 50-DVD set, but not as a stand-alone package.
    All catalog numbers except LaserDisc refer to the shared spine number assigned to all DVD, Blu-ray,
    Essential Art House, and online releases.
    Though some Criterion DVD or Blu-ray releases may go out of press, the films may be re-released in
    different editions through other companies. Occasionally special features produced by Criterion may also
    be included in non-Criterion releases.[7]

    April Fool's pranks[edit]

    • On April Fool's Day 2011, spine #573, which was not yet issued, was assigned to the 1984 movie C.H.U.D.[49]
    • On April Fool's Day 2012, spine #620, which was not yet issued, was assigned to the 1990 movie Kindergarten Cop.[50]

    Boxed sets[edit]

    Further information: List of Criterion Collection boxed sets

    LaserDiscs[edit]

    Further information: List of Criterion Collection LaserDiscs

    Criterion Collection released LaserDiscs from 1984 to 1998. These are now out of print.

    VHS and Betamax cassettes[edit]

    In 1985 and 1989, Criterion Collection released three titles on VHS, Betamax and LaserDisc: The 39 Steps (1935), The Lady Vanishes (1938) and The Third Man (1949), with spine numbers 003–005 respectively.[3] However, they did not sell well, and no more were issued, but they are now collectors' items.[4]
